awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Search for Magneto-electronic Behavior in Complex Fluoride-based Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
There is significant interest in multifunctional materials, such as multiferroics, which combine simultaneous responses to electric, magnetic, and strain fields.  Potential applications include new power efficient electronics and ultra-fast information processing devices.  To date, most of the multiferroics that have been studied are complex oxide materials.  Despite the exciting fundamental discoveries emanating from research on these materials, their multiferroic performance is not yet adequate for use in practical applications.  In this project, the investigators propose to systematically study complex fluoride materials as alternatives to complex oxides because the different physical origins of the multiferroic effects in fluorides can potentially enhance the multiferroic response.  The research will consist of a synergistic collaboration between computational and experimental researchers.  The computational effort will predict the most likely materials to have desired multiferroic properties, and the experimental portion will synthesize and characterize the suggested materials.  In turn, the experimental results will be used to improve the accuracy of the calculations, which ultimately will lead to an efficient optimization of the design of the new materials.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
The goal of this project is to search for and understand the properties of fluoride-based magnetoelectric multiferroic materials.  Recent theoretical work suggests that in ABF3 compounds, ferroelectricity results from the A-site ionic displacement, and not from the magnetic B-site, which should enhance the magnetic response.  This is in contrast to many complex oxides, where it is the magnetic ion site that undergoes the displacement, which at the same time tends to weaken the magnetic properties.  Moreover, the fluorine ions can lead to large canting in antiferromagnetic structures, again enhancing the magnetoelectric response.  There are also indications that interfaces between complex fluorides and other fluorides or oxides should have large and novel magnetoelectric responses.  In this project, the properties of complex fluoride compounds and heterostructures will be studied using ab-initio computational techniques, and the most promising materials will be synthesized via molecular beam epitaxy and characterized using scanning probe and optical techniques.  The experimental results will be used to improve the approximations used in the computational models.  This joint theoretical-experimental effort will efficiently identify the most likely interfaces and materials which have desirable magnetoelectric properties, thus significantly reducing the time necessary for evaluating the vast number of possible material candidates.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project has allowed us to explore the physical-chemical properties of fluoride perovskite-like materials. In this project, we have considered materials with the general formulae ABF3 and ABF4, where F corresponds to the fluorine atom and A and B are cations which guarantee charge neutrality. Usually, A is chosen within periods one or two, while B is chosen from 3d transition metals. The latter aims to also induce a magnetic behavior by incorporating partially occupied d-level atoms. Our understanding of ferroelectrics has taught us that depending on the B cation oxidation state, the equilibrium geometry of the crystal and the ferroelectric properties can be controlled. As such, we have optimized all possible crystal structures starting from the cubic high-symmetry perovskites Pm-3m structure where A = Li, Na, K, and Rb, and B = V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Zn in the ABF3 case. The phonon-dispersion curves unveil possible phase transitions and, if it is the case, the existence of an unstable polar mode can be tuned to design ferroelectricity and the polar response. Our analysis identified that the geometric-like polar instability is present in all the perovskite compounds when A = Li and Na. As such, in the NaMnF3 case, this hidden ferroelectric behavior can be developed by epitaxial strain, latter also confirmed experimentally by us. In the BaMF4 we found that, for M = Co, the multiferroic behavior can be enhanced by strain in thin films, also confirmed experimentally. Interestingly, in the BaCuF4 case, adding the Cu:3d9 electronic occupation as a key ingredient, Jahn-Teller distortion couples to the octahedral rotations to develop a robust magnetoelectric behavior close to room temperature. Summarizing our milestones.

Experimental and theoretical discovery of the first magnetoelectric fluoride perovskite compound: NaMnF3 . We theoretically used first-principles calculations to design the multiferroic/magnetoelectric response in NaMnF3. Later, we successfully achieved the epitaxial thin-films synthesis demonstrating the magnetoelectric response. [A.C. Garcia-Castro et al, Physical Review Letters, 116, 117202 (2016)] and [M. Yang et al,Scientific Reports, 7, 7182, (2017)]

Multiferroic response in BaCoF4 thin films: theoretical and experimental approach. Once we understood the ABF3 family, we moved forward to analyze BaMF4 family, especially, BaCoF4. We studied the magnetic phase transitions induced by strain and its coupling with the layered structure and ferroelectric response. This effect was confirmed experimentally and theoretically alike. [P. Borisov et al, ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, 8, 4, 2694 (2016)]

Magnetoelectricity by design in the BaCuF4 fluoride. After understanding the physics behind the BaCoF4 compound, we added a key ingredient to enhance the magnetoelectric response and increase the functioning temperature. This effect was achieved in the BaCuF4 by designing the coupling with JT-distortion. [A.C. Garcia-Castro, et al, Physical Review Letters, 121, 117601 (2018)].


Unveiling the incipient geometric lattice instability of cubic fluoroperovskites. As we explored, the fluoride perovskites hold a polar mode that strongly depends on the tolerance factor and cation size. Thus, the incipient geometric lattice instability was explored theoretically and experimentally in single crystals. Published as editor's suggestion [R.M. Dubrovin et al, Physical Review B, 104, 144304, (2021)]


Anionic engineering of ferroelectric and magnetic behavior in oxynitride SrNbO3-xNx. Taking advantage of the acquired knowledge in fluorides, we explored the possibility of engineering novel ferroelectrics and magnetic materials by tuning the anionic composition. Thus, following this route, we theoretically designed and explained the ferroelectric response in oxynitrides of the type Sr(Nb,Ta)O3-xNx. These findings were published in [J.S. Gelves-Badillo et al, Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics, 23, (2021). Front Cover]. Additionally, we synthesized the epitaxial thin films confirming the ferroelectric+ferromagnetic response at room temperature. [A.C. Garcia-Castro et al, Advanced Functional Materials, 31, (2021)].

Novel oxyfluoride KTaO3/KZnF3 and KTaO3/KNiF3 superlattices with multifunctional electronic structure. Aiming to explore the anionic engineering, as done in the oxynitrides case, we explored the electronic phenomena in oxide/fluoride superlattice in which we observed a large Rashba spin-splitting at the interface that couples with the magnetic response. [A.C. Garcia-Castro, et al, Physical Review B, 102, 235140, (2020).]


SubMatch Package. A script to search for substrates based on lattice mismatch. The provided material looks for the best substrate with the smaller mismatch with different crystal orientations. It creates a database of all found materials, allowing users to search.


Python interactive tools of different topics in condensed matter physics. We have designed a series of Jupyter notebooks that introduce different topics in condensed matter physics using interactive scripts, where users are allowed to modify model parameters and see the changes in the properties predicted by the particular model. The effort is focused on undergraduate and graduate students. A series of Jupyter notebooks were created introducing different concepts used in condensed matter through python implementation of simple models, where the user can tune the values of the model and understand the physical changes in the property computed from the model.

Modified by: Aldo Romero
